Headline: A waterfall cascading over columnar basalt on the Ardmeanach peninsula
Title: Multi-tiered waterfall
CaptionAbstract:
I spotted this lovely little waterfall on my way to MacCulloch's fossil tree, which is a fossilised cypress-like tree on the tip of the Ardmeanach peninsula on Mull. I say fossilised tree - more accurately it is the cast of one, because Victorian tourists liked their mementos as much as present-day ones and cameras didn't fit in your pocket back then.

On the way back, I struggled to find the waterfall again. I was pretty sure I was in the right place, but it seemed to have disappeared. Surely it hadn't dried up?! After craning my neck up I realised that the wind had picked up and was now blowing the waterfall sideways from where it spilled over the cliff edge high above, dispersing it thinly by the time it reached the ground. I had to wait for a long enough lull in the wind to take the shot I was after.

The columnar basalt created an intriguing multi-tier effect which was what made it jump out to me in the first place. Though I couldn't get far enough away from the towering cliffs to see at the time, I am sure it was also multi-tiered on a much larger scale too, since the Ardmeanach peninsula is where Mull's volcanic origins are most apparent form the stepped "trap" landscape. When I had stayed on the Ross of Mull the previous year, I had often gazed across Loch Scridain to the primeval looking landscape of Mull's most remote area, with its thick, wedding cake-like layers formed by multiple successive lava flows. I had plenty to be getting on with on the Ross of Mull for that trip, but I knew I had to return to visit Ardmeanach some day. I didn't suspect then that it would within less than a year.

Headline: Smooth ripples on Loch Bà reflect Beinn Bhuidhe as it basks in the evening light.
Title: Loch Bà Reflections
CaptionAbstract:
The reflections of the hills behind Loch Bà, basking in the evening light, was what drew my attention to surface of the loch and made me certain there was an image to be made there. Luckily, the breeze was blowing across the loch with just the right strength to create some lovely undulations without them growing big enough to become angular and choppy.

More commonplace subject matter could scarcely be harder (or easier?!) to find, but the confluence of perfect conditions just begged for me to take my camera out.

Keywords: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park
Headline: Oaks in Autumn, with bright orange leaves, on the shore of Loch Drunkie.
Title: Oaks by Loch Drunkie in Autumn
CaptionAbstract: Autumnal oaks overhang the shore of Loch Drunkie, a three-lobed loch in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.

Keywords: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park
Headline: A birch tree covered in thick lichen and moss in Autumn, in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.
Title: Winter Wardrobe
CaptionAbstract: This birch tree has nearly lost all its leaves as autumn creeps onwards. But it won't go into the colder months looking drab; this plunging number from Ralph Lichen's autumn/winter collection, which is bang on trend with its 100% natural materials, will make it stand out from the crowd. Such an excessive amount of both both moss and lichen in one outfit can raise a few eyebrows, sometimes being considered OTT. But this tree has the charisma to pull it off.

Headline: Rowan saplings blanket the ground in Crofton woods.
Title: Rowan Nursery
CaptionAbstract: A cluster of rowan saplings blanketing the ground, taken two springs ago on lockdown wanderings in the woods.

Headline: The light fades at Longwater Lawn in the New Forest, seconds after sunset on the last day of winter. The headwaters of the Beaulieu river meanders towards a tree.
Title: The End of Winter
CaptionAbstract: Seconds after the last sunset of winter, 5 years ago in the New Forest.

Headline: A cairn graces the summit of Suaineabhal (or Suinaval) on the Isle of Lewis.
Title: Suaineabhal Summit
CaptionAbstract: An ascent of Suaineabhal is very much a pick-your-own-route affair, which makes it seem like a much more worthwhile endeavour. Not much point in treading the same path as everyone else, is there?

Headline: Trees in heavy fog on the Grouse Grind trail up Grouse Mountain, near North Vancouver.
Title: Shame About the Fog
CaptionAbstract: I stole the title of the photograph from a Tripadvisor review of Grouse Mountain, one of several which complain about the fog "hampering" the view of Vancouver. I found this quite amusing - personally, it made my day.

Headline: A long exposure of the sea lapping at a boulder-strewn shore on the Ross of Mull, with a rainbow visible in the direction of mainland Scotland.
Title: The Froth on the Firth
CaptionAbstract:
Not the Firth of Forth, unfortunately, so that is where the alliteration will have to end for today.

This view is from the cliff-edged southern coast of the the Ross of Mull out to the Firth of Lorn and various islands off mainland Scotland.

I took this on my way back from the Carsaig arches - two seriously impressive sea arches that would surely be overrun with millions of tourists if they were a bit easier (and safer) to get to. The rainbow appeared shortly after I left the arches which did make me dither over whether I should go back and try to get three arches in one shot. However given that I was not entirely sure it was in the right position to get a decent composition, plus I was pretty relieved to have made it back to safety and I was already facing the prospect of making much of the journey back along the boulder-strewn shore in darkness, I decided against it.

But I'm happy I still managed to get a decent photo from it. It always seems a shame to let a rainbow go to waste.

Headline: The receding waves leave silver lines of froth leading back to the sea at Carsaig Bay, Mull.
Title: Exhale
CaptionAbstract: When I am editing my own photos, I am frequently struck by the stillness and the silence. In many cases, the reality was quite different.

Keywords: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park
Headline: A beech forest in Autumn, near the shore of Loch Ard in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.
Title: Gone Tomorrow
CaptionAbstract:
A beech forest near the shores of Loch Ard looking at its best.

Every year, Autumn is over way before I've had my fill of it, as if the trees either don't realise or don't care what a show they're putting on as they discard leaves they no longer have use for in order to conserve resources and survive. The one good thing about this hasty indifference though, is that it stops you from taking Autumn for granted.

Headline: A Mahonia starts changing to its Autumn colours in Clyne Gardens, Swansea.
Title: A Change for the Better
CaptionAbstract: A sign that Autumn is well on the way in Clyne Gardens.

Headline: Patterns left in the sand by the retreating tide at Whiteford Sands on the Gower Peninsula, Wales.
Title: Maritime Motif
CaptionAbstract:
I loved the patterns left on the beach at Whiteford Sands on the Gower Peninsula. Although the patterns repeated over quite large areas, every so often the pattern would change to something distinctly different, as if the sea had got bored of doing the same thing over and over again and decided to move on to something new.

This particular pattern looks a bit like tyre tracks, but is completely naturally formed.

Headline: A waterfall swollen by heavy rains on Levers Water Beck in the Lake District.
Title: In the Spray Zone
CaptionAbstract: I'm not sure if this waterfall, on Levers Water Beck in the Lake District, is anything special usually... but after days of rain brought by the remnants of Hurricane Gonzalo, which had blown in off the Atlantic the previous week, it's raw power was an invigorating sight to witness.

Headline: An ancient, lichen-encrusted piece of wood, once a majestic tree, forms a natural piece of art.
Title: Abstract #2
Sublocation: Shingle Hill on the Greensand Way
CaptionAbstract: An ancient, lichen-encrusted piece of wood, once a majestic tree, forms a natural piece of art.

Headline: A double rainbow arches between Loch Brittle and Sgùrr nan Gobhar on the Isle of Skye.
Title: Rainbow Valley
CaptionAbstract:
I'm not afraid to admit it: until just now I didn't know the colours on the outer rainbow are reversed compared to the colours on the inner rainbow. But then what normal person could remain level-headed enough to notice something like that when presented with such a sight.

This double rainbow here arches between Loch Brittle and Sgùrr nan Gobhar on the Isle of Skye.

Headline: Moss on the bark of an old oak tree
Title: Mossy Oak

Headline: The sun fingers some bushes and a rocky outcrop in Mojave National Preserve.
Title: Granite Mountains
CaptionAbstract:
A couple of years ago I went to the US on what is possibly the most spontaneous business trip ever to have occurred (Thursday: "Where do you fancy going?", and we were on a plane to Los Angeles on Friday morning!).

One day saw us driving back to LA through the Mojave National Preserve. It was definitely a mixed blessing being in a new and amazing place while being somewhat limited in my ability to get out and explore it properly. Thankfully the desert is a kind place to the photographer and we happened to be there at the right time of day, so it didn't take long to find some half-decent compositions during a road-side stop by the Granite Mountains.

Headline: Red sorrel (rumex acetosella) in long grass is blown by strong wind near Devil's Dyke, Sussex.
Title: Sorrel in the Wind
CaptionAbstract: Trying to capture a sense of the power of the wind that day. Taken at the bottom of Devil's Dyke in Sussex.

Headline: Leaves of a grey tree pincushion (Leucospermum conocarpodendron) in Kew Gardens, showing the fine silvery hairs which give the leaves their grey appearance.
Title: Cripplewood
CaptionAbstract:
A grey tree pincushion in the Temperate House at Kew Gardens. The common Afrikaans name Kreupelhout translates to “Cripplewood”, referring to the bent and twisted growth that the branches can exhibit.

Although abundant, grey tree pincushion is classed as vulnerable due to not only the usual threats of habitat loss, but also the reduction of the population of native ants, which the grey tree pincushion relies on for seed dispersal, at the hands of alien ant species. Ants are attracted to the elaiosomes (fleshy structures attached to the seeds) and the native ants carry the seeds back to their nests to eat the elaiosomes, where the seeds are protected underground from fires as well as from being eaten by other animals. After a fire, the seeds then germinate. Invasive ants, on the other hand, are less concerned about the sustainability of their food source and gorge on the elaiosomes without performing the necessary duties, leaving the seeds unprotected from fire.

But then the invasive ants would hardly be upholding the spirit of colonialism if they didn't ride roughshod over their new turf with complete indifference to the long-term ecological consequences of disrupting the delicate balance in which their evictees had lived in harmony for millennia.

Headline: An orange-red sunset falls over Uig Bay on the Isle of Lewis and Harris
Title: Hebridean Rhythms
CaptionAbstract:
Surprisingly, though I remember the day clearly, I have no recollection of taking this particular photograph and was quite surprised by it when going through my library. There were a lot of interesting things going on with the light that evening, and given that this was such an easy shot to take - no need to carefully compose with the foreground for example - I guess it didn't really register that much and was pushed out of my mind by other images from that day which took more deliberation to make, and which I probably thought stronger at the time.

Still a good one though, I'd say.

Headline: Sea thrift and lichen on coastal rocks on the Isle of Arran.
Title: Sea Thrift
CaptionAbstract: Sea thrift and lichen brighten up some coastal rocks near Newton Point on the Isle of Arran.

Headline: A tranquil view of Uig Bay from Uig Beach on the Isle of Lewis.
Title: Longer Days to Come
CaptionAbstract:
A view from Uig Beach on an evening when the light just kept on giving and giving. So much so that I was still up shooting after it had turned 11pm, though that might also have had something to do with being nearly as close to Iceland as to London only 2 weeks before the summer solstice.

The slope of Uig Beach is extremely shallow, and so the rising tide devours the beach at a brisk rate. I clambered up and hover Machair Carnish to Tràigh Bhoisadair (Bhoisadair Beach) shortly after taking this shot, and by the time I came back an hour or two later there was no option but to get my socks wet.

Headline: A woodland scene showing a Dryopteris Affinis fern with striking croziers by East Kyd Brook in Crofton Woods, with Crofton Heath beyond.
Title: Cradle of Life
CaptionAbstract:
Ferns are in abundance right now by East Kyd Brook. The new fronds of hart's-tongue are charming and maybe I will post a photo of those soon, but this Dryopteris Affinis has been on my radar since I explored along the brook a couple of weeks ago.

Confusingly, East Kyd Brook, as it is labelled on maps when it is labelled at all, is to the west of Kyd Brook. Perhaps there is or was another branch of the tributary of the River Quaggy somewhere further to the west, though if so then it is probably somewhat hidden and inaccessible now due to housing around.

Local historian Paul Browning's blog Running Past provides an amazingly forensic account of the River Quaggy and it's tributaries - a herculean task. OS maps don't help much and it was always a mystery to me where the Kyd Brook came from and where it went when periodically disappearing from the map.

Headline: A flash of new-growth green in Meenfied wood near Shoreham, putting on one of the UK's best displays of bluebells.
Title: A Few Thousand of my Favourite Things
CaptionAbstract:
Bluebells, bluebells and bluebells... these are a few thousand of my favourite things. More, probably. I didn't count them all.

This is the best location that I know of to see one of the UK's best seasonal displays. Unfortunately I probably won't be able to get there this year now un-necessary travel is banned, but the bluebells in the woods near my house are coming along nicely. Nothing to match Shoreham woods, but nothing to be sniffed at either.

Headline: A small spider in a tiny web, on a Black Lace Elder plant (Sambuca Nigris) backlit by the sun.
Title: Born to spin
CaptionAbstract: A tiny spider in a tiny web on a Black Lace elder plant. This brilliantly simple but effective design has been independently reinvented by every spider that ever lived. Because spiders don't need to be taught how to spin a web - they are just born with the instinct.

Headline: Some grassy mounds emerge from very wet and boggy ground in Gleann Easan Biorach on the Isle of Arran.
Title: The Hard Path
CaptionAbstract: The going gets a little tough in Gleann Easan Biorach.

Headline: A long exposure of an illuminated tree at night in Petts Wood, with orange clouds and stars out.
Title: Alone in the Woods

Headline: An abstract photo. See in it what you will.
Title: Abstract #1

Headline: Snow-capped mountains near Tromsø, Northern Sweden a couple of weeks from the start of the Polar Night.
Title: Last Light
CaptionAbstract:
A permanent sort of ethereal twilight pervades during the last weeks before the Polar Night arrives. The sun only rises a couple of degrees above the true horizon, so is completely blocked by the mountains.

This view is looking down the valley of the Sørbotnelva, which flows towards the camera into the Ramfjord at Sørbotn, just hidden from sight.

Headline: The last surviving snow from last year's snowfall, with rocks and a mountain in the background.
Title: Survivor
CaptionAbstract: Taken on an overnight hiking trip to some cabins near Tromsø. It was mid-November and snow had not yet fallen, so this was the last remains from the previous year. With less than 2 weeks to go until permanent night time, the sun no longer rose high enough for this snow to have to endure it's direct rays, so it would live to see another (polar) day.

Headline: Sheep looking at the camera in a field adjacent to the Swale National Nature Reserve on the Isle of Sheppey.
Title: Sheep Island
CaptionAbstract:
These sheep are natural models, and didn't need any direction from me to form this pleasing positioning.

The Isle of Sheppey is an island in the Thames Estuary, and its name is derived from Old English Sceapig, meaning "Sheep Island". Besides sheep, it is also home to a creature you would be slightly more surprised to find in the UK — the European yellow-tailed scorpion, which hitched a ride from Italy on a ship in the 18th century and found the UK climate not too disagreeable, apparently. They can survive here thanks to an extremely slow metabolism, only bothering to move for the strict essentials of hunting for food (which sometimes includes each other) and mating.

Headline: A thick-trunked oak tree in Crofton woods, leafless and covered in ivy and moss in winter.
Title: The Other Side
CaptionAbstract: I had spotted this oak tree some distance off the path during my walks in Crofton woods, and had been intending to return with my camera to capture what looked, at least from a distance, like a promising subject. When I finally did, and went off the path to approach the it, I was shocked to discover that it was right next to another path that I had walked along several times before, completely failing to notice this ancient oak as anything of particular interest from the other side, from which it's verdant cloak was not visible. It just goes to show what a change of direction can do, and also just how disorienting woods can be. Even when you think you know them, they still have the ability to surprise you.

Headline: A wind-fallen branch, encrusted in lichen, lies in a flooded path, with trees reflected.
Title: After Brendan
CaptionAbstract:
Watching the heavy rain and strong winds as Storm Brendan raged outside, I knew that there would be some good photos to be had after it had all died down. I got to Crofton Woods maybe slightly later than I had hoped and it was already pretty dark, but I had brought my headtorch with me so it was the perfect time to try out a bit of light painting.

This branch is lying in what is usually a path, only it was flooded as far as I could see (at least by the light of my headtorch) and deeper than Kyd Brook is most of the time. I spent quite a while improving the technique of illuminating all of the different bits of it evenly without illuminating any of the water, and by the time I had finished it was almost pitch black.

Headline: Two birch trees stand among densely packed, red-brown bracken in Autumn in a woodland, with the sun close to the horizon.
Title: Monoculture
CaptionAbstract: Where bracken grows, little else can. It ruthlessly outcompetes other plants, and some studies have also shown that when it dies back, the rain leaches toxins from it which inhibits other plant growth.

Keywords: Wye Valley Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty
Headline: A small-leaved lime tree with the last of its fruits in winter, with a misty woodland background.
Title: The Last of Autumn's Bounty
CaptionAbstract:
When I stopped for lunch under this small-leaved lime tree during a walk along part of Offa's Dyke Path, I didn't realise that it would also give me the strongest image of the day.

Small-leaved limes are indicators of ancient woodland in the UK, and this lime tree is not lying - the misty backdrop you see here is Cadora woods, one of the many areas of ancient woodland in the Wye Valley.

Headline: A birch tree is illuminated by the full moon in a wood.
Title: Moonbolt
CaptionAbstract: The moon throws down a bolt of light, using this birch tree as its vehicle. I took a spontaneous moonlit stroll through the woods near my house on the recent full moon, and it reminded me of the last time I did so, when I took my camera and made this photo. I'm planning to plan ahead next time and take my camera out on the next full moon.

Headline: A clump of ferns cluster around a large rock in a glacial valley, with Cir Mhor in the background,
Title: Green Embrace
CaptionAbstract: A clump of ferns cluster around a boulder in Glen Sannox on the Isle of Arran. Arran is a mecca for students of geology, who swarm to the island in summer months, and are known affectionately (I presume) to the locals as "Jolly Boys". I guess it's hard not to be happy when surrounded by a magnificent glacial landscape such as this. I think the gender balance in the Earth Sciences is better than it used to be: perhaps the phrase has remained unchanged because it has a certain ring to it.

Headline: Barnacles create a streak of white on black schist on the North coast of Arran.
Title: Barnacle Unconformity
CaptionAbstract: These barnacles are jostling for space so much here that at first glance it looks like there is a junction between two types of rock, which is actually what I thought was the case at first. If you do want to find 2 different types of rocks adjoining each other, then not far from here you will find Hutton's Unconformity, one of several places noted by geologist James Hutton where different types of rocks of different ages are found adjoining each other, with the younger rock on top. Hutton used such locations as evidence for his theory of how the Earth's crust is continually undergoing the same natural processes today which formed it as it is in the present day. This theory of Uniformitarianism, as it was called, challenged the then accepted idea that the Earth was only a few thousand years old. That was in the late 18th century, but it was only in the early 20th century that estimates of the age of the Earth reached the billions rather than millions of years, at least without being largely ignored.

Headline: 2 men waiting at a bus stop on a very steep road in Chinatown, San Francisco
Title: Lean-to

Headline: 3 cows grazing, with the Cuillin peak of  Blà Bheinn in the background.
Title: Beneath Blà Bheinn
CaptionAbstract: Taken from near the shore of Loch Slapin, where the road makes a sharp U-turn to circumvent it on the way to Elgol. To me, the cows and sheep are as integral a part of the Skye landscape as the sweeping sea lochs and lofty peaks.

Headline: A view of the Black Cuillins across Loch Scavaig
Title: Loch Scavaig
CaptionAbstract: A view across Loch Scavaig towards Gars-bheinn and the Black Cuillin surrounding Loch Coruisk, appropriately cast into shadows by the clouds.

Headline: A streak of white sand on a mostly black volcanic sand beach in Glen Brittle, Isle of Skye.
Title: Neptune's Canvas
CaptionAbstract: A streak of white sand marbles the mostly black volcanic sand of Glen Brittle beach. Twice a day, the sea leaves patterns of light and dark on the beach before, etch-a-sketch style, erasing everything and starting again.

Headline: Cows by Loch Brittle on Rubha an Dùnain, the Isle of Skye.
Title: Cows by Loch Brittle
CaptionAbstract: Cows by Loch Brittle on Rubha an Dùnain, the Isle of Skye.

Headline: Northern gannet colony at Boreray, St. Kilda
Title: Boreray
CaptionAbstract: Boreray, part of the St. Kilda archipelago, wastes no time getting to the point, being the smallest Scottish island with an elevation of over 1000ft. It is home to the world's 2nd largest colony of northern gannet, which were the staple food of the St. Kildans for most of the island's history, until a demand for fulmar products (oil and feathers) in the 18th century persuaded them to develop a taste for the smaller bird. Despite being even more inhospitable than Hirta, the main island of the archipelago, archaeological evidence suggests Boreray was inhabited at one point. In more recent times, Boreray was only temporarily inhabited for the purposes of catching gannets and puffins (the latter quarry being reserved for the women), and tending the semi-feral sheep. When in distress, communication was made with Hirta by inverting patches of turf, the position and size of which could signify either lack of provisions, illness, injury or death.

Headline: Visitors at the Natural History Museum in London examine a display of insects in Hintze Hall.
Title: Insect exhibit at Hintze Hall
CaptionAbstract: Pretty busy at the Natural History Museum, even before you count the tourists.

Headline: Tyre tracks leading towards a field of sheep  in Shoreham, Kent.
Title: Tyre Tracks at Dusk
CaptionAbstract:
If you're walking the Darent Valley Path from Sevenoaks to the Thames, Shoreham is one of the most delightful places you will pass through on the way, and well worth planning a bit of extra time for. Its woods in particular—; including Meenfield wood, which is the one you can see in this photo — are carpeted with blubells in the spring.

It's amazing that I took this photo over 2 years ago, but haven't had time to upload it here (or any other photos for that matter, until last weekend) since starting my job shortly before this photo was taken. Hopefully I will start getting back into the swing of things now. I guess I let this website slip down a bit in my priorities, but I have recently decided to bump it up to number 2 in my list (after surviving/paying the bills).

Anyway, I would highly recommend doing the Darent Valley Path if you live in the south-east London Area. Someone I met once told me that tears came to his eyes when he reached the sea after walking the length of the Thames. You will probably manage to keep dry eyes upon reaching the muddy banks of the Thames after following the journey of its little tributary, but it's still a worthwhile excursion if you only have a day to spare.

Headline: A roe deer leaps through the grass at Chobham common, white rump patch on display.
Title: Roe Deer Scarpering
CaptionAbstract: I got the distinct impression that my presence wasn't appreciated by this roe deer and its fellow herdmembers when I stumbled upon their drinking spot. This female gave me a display of its white rump patch as it bounded away through the grass.

Keywords: Church of St. John the Baptist
Headline: A man in a leather jacket walking down a narrow street, with a medieval church in the background.
Title: Black Jack Street
CaptionAbstract: Looking down Black Jack Street in Cirencester, towards the Church of St. John the Baptist.

Headline: Spray artist Tony Vegas displays a finished painting in the Fremont Street Experience, Las Vegas.
Title: Tony Vegas
CaptionAbstract: Me editing my photos could hardly be called a spectator sport. This guy, on the other hand, has turned making art into an art form. Vying for attention with contortionists, musicians and other street performers, Tony Vegas produces his paintings in frenzies of movement, sound and colour which draw sizeable crowds. He is seen here showing off a finished creation at the Fremont Street Experience. See him making a painting in just under 7 minutes here.

Headline: Rain falls from dark clouds above a red-orange landscape of hoodooes and coniferous trees.
Title: Rain over Bryce Canyon

Headline: Dasylirion leiophyllum (green sotol) in the University of California Botanical Garden.
Title: Green Sotol
CaptionAbstract: Dasylirion leiophyllum (commonly known as green sotol or smooth-leaf sotol) in the University of California Botanical Garden. It is native to North American, and common in the Chihuahan desert. The word "sotol" appears in the common names of many other species in this genus of the asparagus family. The distilled spirit sotol, however, is made from Dasylirion wheeleri, or desert spoon.

Headline: A puddle meanders towards a cow by the Severn Estuary, with a lighthouse on a small island in the background.
Title: Cow Pooing at Black Rock
CaptionAbstract: I managed to snap this cow with it's poo in mid-air (I hope it's not a reflection on what she thinks of my photo). Henri Cartier-Bresson would be proud.

Headline: Dead trees at Main Terrace in Mammoth Hot Springs.
Title: Mammoth Hot Springs
CaptionAbstract: Mammoth Hot Springs is a complex of hot springs in Yellowstone National Park. Travertine, a form of limestone deposited by the hot springs, is abundant here, and in places is tinted red, brown, orange or green by algae. Behind and on the right is Mount Everts.

Headline: A Zanzibari man looking up from his newspaper in a Stone Town alley.
Title: Cosy Reading Spot
CaptionAbstract: A local of Stone Town, Zanzibar, looks up from his Swahili newspaper. This was the first time I plucked up the courage to take a photo of a stranger from close range.

Headline: A close-up of a Grant's zebra (Equus quagga boehmi) in Ngorongoro Conservation Area.
Title: Zebra, Ngorongoro Crater
CaptionAbstract: One of a large herd of Zebras and Wildebeest in Ngorongoro Crater, the world's largest inactive, unfilled volcanic caldera.

Headline: A padlocked garage door with peeling paint and No Parking sign.
Title: 24h Access Required
Sublocation: 23 Park Street, formerly Henry Tanner's Chapel
CaptionAbstract:
I was drawn to the peeling paint and rust on this garage door, and only later when looking at Google Maps did I see that I had missed the little blue plaque right next to it. It was erected by the Cirencester Civic Society and reads:

23 Park Street. Formerly Henry Tanner's chapel, opened in 1854 for strict Baptists seceding from the Baptist Chapel in Coxwell Street

Headline: The Coca-Cola London Eye, then the EDF Energy London Eye, at night viewed from below.
Title: The London Eye
CaptionAbstract: The London Eye looking pretty at night before it turned a sickly shade of Coca-Cola.

Headline: A man rolling a huge tyre along a dust road in Arusha, Tanzania.
Title: Rapid Roadside Assistance

Headline: A man walking his dog over a weir at Levers Water reservoir in the Lake District.
Title: Weir Walking
CaptionAbstract: Braving the elements, a group of walkers wait for an ebb in the flow of water over Levers Water weir to make a crossing.

Headline: A hunched elderly man with walking stick walking across the Savoy Hotel entrance.
Title: World in a Hurry
CaptionAbstract: A London city worker on his commute along the Strand, with the festively decorated entrance to the Savoy Theatre in the background.

Headline: Fallow deer on a hill top with two Scots Pine trees in Knole Park.
Title: Deer at Dusk
CaptionAbstract: A herd of fallow deer stretch out along a hill top after sunset in Knole Park, with two Scots Pine trees illuminated from the side by the orange glow lingering in the sky.

Headline: Black Rock, along the River Severn in Monmouthshire. A cow and Charston Rock Lighthouse lie in the background.
Title: Cow and Lighthouse
CaptionAbstract: A solitary cow munches grass on the waterlogged banks of the River Severn at Black Rock. In the background, Charston rock lighthouse sits primed for action.

Headline: A male lion lying down in grass in Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Tanzania.
Title: Ngorongoro Lion
CaptionAbstract: A male lion in Ngorongoro Conservation Area in Tanzania.

Headline: A tree stump in Meenfield Wood
Title: Sunstruck Stump
CaptionAbstract: I didn't set out to photograph these two tree stumps, but the setting sun came out from behind the clouds to create such an enticing composition that I thought it would be rude not to.

Headline: People in a crowded Darajani market in Zanzibar City, some wearing bargashia (traditional hats similar to the kofia).
Title: Bazaar
CaptionAbstract: Darajani Market, the main market of Stone Town Zanzibar, is mainly a food market, but this section sells a variety of other goods. Several men are wearing bargashia hats (like the kofia, but embroidered and lacking in pin holes), which are popular in Tanzania and northern Uganda.

Headline: Sunrise at Villach Hauptbahnhof (train station) where a timber laden train waits to set off.
Title: Villach Sunrise
CaptionAbstract: Sunrise at Villach Hauptbahnhof, just before this timber-laden train set off. Being a nocturnal creature, I don't get to see many sunrises, so I was quite excited by this.

Headline: The dazzling light show at the Fremont Street Experience and a girl in a white hat. Also a man dressed as Superman.
Title: In Amazing Technicolor
CaptionAbstract: This light show in Fremont Street was Downton Vegas' fightback against the gradual migration of activity the Strip. In attempt to lure back visitors, after the CEO of Paramount pictures refused permission to build a Starship Enterprise I thought this girl, standing alone, would make the perfect foreground to the light show. As I walked towards her, I suddenly realised that her perfect position was not as fortuitous as I first though - I saw in my peripheral vision she was with a friend and he was taking pictures of her, and that I was walking right in-between them! Fortunately he didn't notice as he had his eye to the viewfinder, and she didn't notice as she was looking the other way, giving me a chance to avoid the embarrassment, taking a position behind and to this side of him, profiting from his good directing. Thanks random dude!

Headline: A mute swan swimming in a pond at Caldicot Castle, with a tree and reflection in the background.
Title: Swan in a Tree
CaptionAbstract: This mute swan positioned itself perfectly for me in a pond in the grounds behind Caldicot Castle.

Headline: Love locks on the Pont des Arts in Paris.
Title: 45 Metric Tons of Love
CaptionAbstract: Padlocks left on the Pont des Arts in Paris by lovers young and old. The keys were thrown into the Seine according to ancient tradition. Not really though - the "tradition" only lasted for 7 years. By 2015 they numbered around the million mark and were removed for the sake of the bridge's structural integrity. The bridge is now decorated with padlock-themed street art on light-weight and unpadlockable wooden boards.

Headline: A man roller skating over a zebra crossing in Paris, with a family walking behind going in the opposite direction.
Title: Paris Street Roller
CaptionAbstract: An inline skater rolls over a zebra crossing on the quai des Célestins in le quartier de l'Arsenal.

Headline: A cluster of water lilies with flowers in the Monet Pool at Denver Botanic Gardens.
Title: Monet Pool
CaptionAbstract: The Monet pool in Denver Botanic Gardens is home to 150 species of the water lily, the plant that made Claude Monet so famous. I had left my easel at home, so went for a more photorealistic interpretation here.

Headline: An abstract image of heather with purple flowers and a birch branch on Chobham common. The camera was rotated during the exposure
Title: Heather Eddy
CaptionAbstract: An abstraction of newly enflowered heather and a fallen birch branch on Chobham Common.

Headline: Shadows of passers-by in front of the London Eye.
Title: Shadow Play

Headline: A Mini Cooper lit by a street light at night in Orpington.
Title: Insomnia

Headline: A long and straight tree-lined footpath ending at the horizon in the Bathurst Estate, Cirencester.
Title: X

Headline: A man wearing Converse shoes walking past a shoe shop on Oxford Street at Christmas.
Title: Shoe Shop

Headline: Star trails and shooting star in the Lake District, with a disused mine shaft tower in silhouette.
Title: Disused Mine Shaft and Star Trails
CaptionAbstract: After a day of extremely heavy rain while I was staying in the Coppermines Valley near Coniston, the sky cleared for the first and pretty much only time during my visit to the Lake District. I decided to head back to this disused mine shaft, The Old Engine Shaft, to try and capture some star trails. I was curious what exactly the tower was used for. Apparently it held a trough feeding a huge water wheel which powered the pump and winding gear used in the shaft. Well done if you spotted the shooting star. This occurred within the first few frames so I was lucky enough to see it with my own eyes. Later I would have been too busy alternating between trying to sleep and trying to keep warm to notice it. Neither with much luck.

Headline: A little egret (Egretta garzetta) taking off from a cable over the river Danube in evening light.
Title: An Egret's Egress

Headline: The interior of Sainte Chapelle, showing the stained glass windows and vaulted ceiling.
Title: Inside God's Jewelry Box
CaptionAbstract: If you ever find yourself in a flurry to see the sights in Paris, do you self a favour - give the massive queues for Notre Dame a miss and pay a visit to Sainte Chapelle instead. What Notre Dame's less visited neighbour may lack in brutish grandeur, it makes up for in this; an impossible ratio of spindly stone to dazzling glass that will make you question how the roof stays up.

Headline: A sheep running in warm sunlight in a field in Shoreham, Kent
Title: Baaalmy Afternoon

Headline: The view up Hauptplatz in Villach, with St. Jakob's Church in the background.
Title: Villach Sleeping
CaptionAbstract: There's nothing quite like experiencing a place for the first time before everyone's woken up. I spent just two hours in Villach; long enough to catch the sunrise back at the station before catching a train to Belgrade.

Headline: Five Grant's zebras walking across a plain in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania.
Title: Zebras of the Serengeti
CaptionAbstract: Zebras roaming the plains in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania.

Headline: The roof of the LDS Conference Centre in Salt Lake City, showing reflecting pool and spire.
Title: LDS Conference Center
CaptionAbstract: A 92 foot tower atop the roof of this building (yes roof, don't be fooled by the trees) gives a clue as to its religious significance, serving as the premier meeting place of the Mormon Church and housing, for this purpose, the largest theatre style auditorium in the world. Just walk into the building and in true Mormon style, someone will be there to greet you, eager to give you a tour. Out of view to the right is what is surely Salt Lake City's finest roof-top garden, so it's well worth a visit.

Headline: Three pine trees lit by the setting sun at Chobham common in Surrey.
Title: Evening at Chobham Common

Headline: Chickens for sale at a market in Stone Town, Zanzibar.
Title: Chickens for Sale
CaptionAbstract: Chickens in market in Stone Town, Zanzibar.

Headline: A view of the Shard from London Waterloo East Railway Station at night.
Title: Next Stop: The Shard

Headline: An impala in Tarangire National Park, Tanzania
Title: Impala in the Grass
CaptionAbstract: An impala in Tarangire National Park - not the largest National Park in Tanzania, but home to an incredibly diverse mix of landscape and vegetation.

Headline: A leafless canopy and blue sky in Shoreham Wood, Kent.
Title: Empty Canopy
CaptionAbstract: The canopy is bare in Shoreham woods, but not for much longer: spring is just around the corner. Shoreham woods puts on its best show in the spring, playing host to a legion of bluebells.

Headline: A leafless baobab tree (Adansonia digitata) in Tarangire National Park, Tanzania.
Title: Baobab Tree
